title: Mont-Fallère
text:
The Mont-Fallère or Mont Fallère (sometimes wrongly spelled in Italian as "Fallere") is a 3,061.5 metres high <a href="mountain">mountain</a> belonging to the Italian side of <a href="Pennine%20Alps">Pennine Alps</a>.
Geography.
The Mont-Fallère is located on the ridge dividing the "<a href="Great%20St%20Bernard%20Pass">Great St Bernard</a> Valley" (North and East) from the "<a href="Valdigne">Valdigne</a>", a term and used to define the upper part of the <a href="Aosta%20Valley">Aosta Valley</a>. Administratively the mountain is the <a href="tripoint">tripoint</a> connecting the Italian <a href="comune">comune</a>s of <a href="Sarre%2C%20Aosta%20Valley">Sarre</a>, <a href="Gignod">Gignod</a> and <a href="Saint-Pierre%2C%20Aosta%20Valley">Saint-Pierre</a>.
SOIUSA classification.
According to <a href="SOIUSA">SOIUSA</a> ("International Standardized Mountain Subdivision of the Alps") the mountain can be classified in the following way:
Access to the summit.
The mountain can be accessed by signposted routes or from "Thouraz" (1.652 m), a village in the <a href="comune">comune</a> of <a href="Sarre%2C%20Aosta%20Valley">Sarre</a>, or from Vétan (<a href="Saint-Pierre%2C%20Aosta%20Valley">Saint-Pierre</a>). Both of them require some <a href="hiking">hiking</a> experience. The top of Mont-Fallère offers a good point of view on <a href="Mont%20Blanc">Mont Blanc</a>, <a href="Grand%20Combin">Grand Combin</a>, <a href="Grivola">Grivola</a> and many other peaks of the <a href="Graian%20Alps">Graian</a> and <a href="Pennine%20Alps">Pennine Alps</a>.
